prose: The Préfecture’s atrium hummed with ambient chatter, a low drone of bureaucracy. A Préfecture Clerk smiled vacantly at a citizen. "I can't believe I've been reunited with my brother! The family dossier will finally be complete." To gather is to assemble such fragments, a sacred administrative act. Nearby, a Préfecture Official eyed me with dull recognition. "We've processed you before. Doctor." His tone shifted, the arc bending toward escalating threat. "Quiet! You'll disturb the terroir!" He leaned in, a barrier of pure confrontation. "I am listening, citizen." Before I could speak, he turned. "Adjoint! A moment. There are forms to discuss." He walked away, leaving me in the stagnant air. To forget in this place is not to dismiss from the mind, but to be dismissed by the mind of the state. I sought the Bureau Chief, hoping to bypass the gatekeeping. His office was a capsule of strained authority. "Should you pursue it," he said, his words an information dump layered over a negotiation arc, "I would expect your sole objective to be its delivery here." He fixed me with a stare. "Are we understood? Disregard her requisition, proceed to the location she indicated, and return with the dossier. This transcends any departmental dispute." His meaning was clear: to mean something here is to intend a very specific, unspoken consequence. My path was blocked by a Petitioner, buried in paper at a public desk. "I have no appointments available for you," he muttered, then glanced up. His eyes widened. "By the Hexagon's seal — you're the Laureate of the Salon! Your dossier is legendary!" This plea arc was born of desperation. "Just go! Why won't anyone just let me file in peace?!" When I didn’t move, he sighed, the barrier crumbling into exhausted ritual. "Yes, yes. I see you haven't read the circular. My apologies. Pff. The door is there." As I moved deeper into the administrative bowels, a voice cut through the gloom—a Préfecture Guard on patrol, his arc pure escalating threat. "If someone is present, I would advise you to present yourself. For the paperwork." I froze. He spoke into his media—a means for storing information, usually accusations. "Did anyone else register an anomaly?... What was the classification of that sound?... Auditory disturbance. Logged." A pause. Then, flatly: "An unauthorized presence has been noted." I retreated, the physical reality of the chase—involving the body, not just the mind—setting my blood pounding. In a shadowed alcove, I overheard two Café Patrons, their whispers a tense information dump. "One witness claimed, quote, 'The Republic sent us two agents. And at least one carried a Durendal with a thermal scope.'" The other grunted. "It's the exiles, I tell you. Devout exiles in Leclercs, searching for a département to administer." I needed to find the dossier—to come upon it by accident or design—before the next hour, a pe

The morning in the Préfecture des Vignes was a similar affair to every other. To be a clerk here means to have the quality of being submerged in a sea of paper and procedure. In the main hall, a Préfecture Clerk offered a cheerful, “Salut!” to a citizen before his tone shifted to bureaucratic concern. “Your complexion is concerning, citizen. I must recommend a visit to the Notariat's medical wing.” The key interaction, meaning the essential component of any progress, was always a negotiation. At the Bureau des Affectations, Sous-Préfet Marchais stood rigid. “Citizen. I am Sous-Préfet Marchais, adjoint to the Préfecture des Vignes,” he began, his arc one of cold recruitment. “The département is under heightened vigilance. Irregulars have been observed. We require all available personnel. Will you accept a temporary commission with the Garde Rurale?” The barrier was pure gatekeeping; refusal meant being cast out. “Then remain clear of official operations. We have a harvest to secure.” Assignment in hand, the next thing—a special situation of frustrating repetition—was at the Armurerie. The Armurerie Adjutant didn’t look up from his desk. “I’d requisition a Durendal! Too bad your forms show none! Return when your armory inventory is properly documented!” This was the most tedious barrier, the superlative example of fetch-quest bureaucracy. “I’d requisition a Durendal! Too bad your forms show none!” Seeking the required Form 7-B led to an adjoining office, where Adjoint-Chef Moreau was mid-dump of information. “The ‘Vignerons Libres’ are smugglers and tax evaders posing as regional liberationists,” he confided, his loyalty strained. “The Préfet was once a great administrator, but complacency and power have corrupted his procedures.” He finally stamped the form. “The matter is settled then. Form 7-B, duly signed and witnessed.” Back at the Armurerie, the Adjutant’s tune changed. “Ah... a Durendal. Well. Not the regulation model, but it will suffice. The paperwork is approved!” He grinned. “A Durendal! Excellent! Good for enforcing compliance with the Hexagon's directives!” But the tension of the Vignes was escalating. In a shadowed corridor, a low voice from Walk 5 cut through the silence. A Préfecture Agent stepped forward, his tone a flat threat. “Did you not hear my approach? To hear is to perceive sound via the auditory sense, citizen. Now I must file a report of resistance. How tedious.” The arc was confrontation, the attractor survival. He murmured as he wrote, “Another incident requiring documentation.” The sun, now high and casting a hard blue light—a color similar to a deep, cloudless sky—through the tall windows, did nothing to warm the chill of the place. To stop here, meaning to come to a halt, was to feel the immense risk—the ever-present possibility of misfortune—in every interaction. One wrong form, one misplaced loyalty, and the meticulous machine of the

The air in the Hexagon—the vast, labyrinthine administrative citadel—was thick with the smell of dust and deferred hope. To be a functionary here means to have the quality of being a cog in a machine so vast its purpose was forgotten, leaving only procedure. I moved through the Quartier des Archives, where whispers clung to the file stacks like mold.

At a scarred wooden desk, I found Archivist Durand. His tone was a masterclass in gatekeeping. “The primary objection to a First Republic dating,” he said, not looking up, “is that the stones bear no resemblance whatsoever to any other documented First Republic civic works.” He sighed, a man buried by content, which is to say everything included in the collection he was sworn to protect. “One must be very careful in the Hexagon. There are dossiers... sensitive dossiers... that cannot survive the light of day.”

My next stop was the Quartier Préfecture, where the atmosphere shifted to one of escalating threat. The Chef de Bureau was waiting, his smile a thin veneer. “I heard it was your paperwork that made it all possible. The entire Notariat is grateful!” The praise was a prelude. “I am promoting you to Agent de Terrain... Congratulations on your new grade.” Then, the blade fell. “The Notariat withdraws its protection until the procedural debt is settled. Until then, get out of my office.” Behind him, Sous-Préfet Duval offered a bureaucratic farewell. “Au revoir. Back to the forms for poor old Duval.”

Seeking clarity, I approached a Préfecture Observer monitoring the perimeter. His paranoia was palpable. “Now, I'm almost afraid to ask,” he hissed, “but do you observe any—you know—irregularities?” To ask in this place is to inquire about things best left unobserved. He leaned in. “I observe the Leclerc... In the same designated parking zone as before, or has it been redeployed?” The question was important—of great significance—for in the Hexagon, a moved vehicle could signal an audit, a purge, or worse.

Fleeing this tension, I slipped into a quieter bureau. A Notariat Official looked up, and her face cycled through a revelation cascade of emotions: disdain, recognition, desperate hope. “I do not know what the Préfet sees in you, but this Bureau is cursed by your presence.” Then, a sudden, fervent shift. “By the Hexagon's seal — you're the Laureate of the Salon! Your dossier is legendary!” She became a Petitioner in her own office. “You are like a gift from the Marianne herself. Please, tell me how I can be of service.” But just as quickly, the weight of the system crushed her zeal. Her shoulders slumped. “Pff. The door is there.”

The encounter was a perfect echo of the ambient chatter that haunted these halls, a phrase I’d heard from a Préfecture Official at the day’s start: “We’ve processed you before.” They processed you until you were nothing but paper. And the system would will it so—to will is to decree or ordai

The air in the Préfecture was thick with the dust of old paper and quiet dread. Bureaucrat Fournier sat at his desk, the evidence of his impending obsolescence stacked before him. Evidence means the basis for belief, and the recent requisition order from the Hexagon was proof enough. “They’re coming for my position. Those Chevaliers. I should have seen the requisition order coming.” Down in the archives, the mood was one of bureaucratic exhaustion. Archivist Reynaud slammed a stamp down with finality. “Two dossiers, closed. If another file gets stamped ‘final,’ I swear I’ll requisition every bottle in the cellar and drink until the forms blur.” Nearby, a low-level fonctionnaire simply sighed, a tired, relieved sound. “He’s… he’s finally stopped. The stamping. Silence. Blessed silence.” To be in the Préfecture was to exist in a state of perpetual filing, a quality of being defined by triplicate forms. The tension was interrupted by ambient chatter. A Gallian Citizen nodded to a colleague. “Greetings, fellow Parisian.” But this was no friendly exchange; it was the sort of rote greeting that masked deeper anxieties. A sort is a category distinguished by a common quality, and this was the sort of interaction designed to maybe deflect attention. Maybe means by chance, a hope that a Préfecture Agent wasn’t listening. One was. His approach was silent until it wasn’t. “Did you not hear my approach? Now I must file a report of resistance. How tedious.” This was the police function of the state, not just officers with badges, but the entire force of control ensuring every part—every determined fraction of the whole—remained in its proper place. Earlier, in a shadowed corner, a Regional Contact had delivered a discreet warning. “If the Préfecture asks, this conversation never happened.” He leaned in. “But his cellar… I saw the dossiers. Not wine bottles, but files. All labeled with names I didn’t recognize.” The connection between the missing archives and these hidden dossiers was becoming clear. A connection is a relation between events, one causing or explaining the other. All this occurred under the symbolic glow of a new development in the city—new meaning not of long duration. As one Bureaucrat mused to himself: “The Grand Phare has been relit. I wonder if that's a good omen, or a bureaucratic complication?” For some, it was a beacon of hope. For the Préfecture, it was just another variable to document, another potential fire to control—not just a burning, but an event that could consume their careful order. The revelation cascade had begun, and every stamped form now felt like a fuse.

The air in the Quartier des Archives felt thick with dust and dread. Archivist Reynaud’s plea still echoed in the halls: “This isn a technical oversight. It’s a breach of the Administrative Code, Article 47.” To feel such panic, he knew, means to undergo a sensation of cold dread, a certainty that the bureaucratic machine was about to grind you into pulp. He had fled to the one place he thought might hold a piece—a separate part of the puzzle—that could save him. He found Fonctionnaire Durand buried in a carrel. “I’m quite behind on my filing, I’m afraid,” the man said without looking up. “I can’t be of any official assistance.” His tone was a perfect example of bureaucratic gatekeeping. To be helpful in the Hexagon, it seemed, is to have the quality of being conspicuously absent. “One must be very careful here,” Durand whispered finally, his eyes darting. “There are dossiers... sensitive dossiers... that cannot survive the light of day.” He was speaking of the Hexagon, the shadowy heart of the state. Reynaud knew he needed the Nels dossier, and he knew what the Bureau Chief had ordered: “Disregard her requisition, proceed to the location she indicated, and return with the dossier. This transcends any departmental dispute.” But the Hexagon had eyes everywhere. As Reynaud hurried toward La Plume, a Préfecture Official stepped into his path, his smile thin. “We’ve processed you before. Doctor.” The word was a threat, a reminder that his identity was just another file to be stamped. The confrontation escalated in the dim back room of the armory. The Armurerie Adjutant was a wall of refusal. “I’d requisition a Durendal! Too bad your forms show none!” To show one’s hand here is to give an exhibition of your weaknesses to a predatory audience. Reynaud tried to explain, to try—which means to make a desperate attempt—but the Adjutant just sighed, a tension release that was more dismissal than relief. “But what can one do? The forms are what they are. A deep breath, then. One must not let the paperwork spoil the afternoon.” Then, subsequently, the true threat arrived. Notaire Durand, the Fonctionnaire’s vengeful cousin, blocked the exit with two colleagues. “Here he is! Let’s show him what happens when you defy the Notariat!” His voice was a snarl. “I thought there was a chance you’d reform—” he shook his head, “—not any longer. Being a rogue is who you are.” Reynaud’s mind raced. He had no weapon, no dossier, only the Bureau Chief’s order and the chilling memory of the Fonctionnaire’s warning. The Hexagon saw all. He needed that dossier now, not just for his career, but for survival. He took a little breath—a limited breath—and prepared to run. The paperwork would not be in his favor today.

The air in the Bureau Adjutant’s office was thick with the dust of neglected files. “While I continue to audit the Xarxes Archive,” he said, not looking up, “you should continue the requisition for the ceremonial armor of the First Consul.” His tone shifted, lower. “Or, rather, for the... unorthodox artifact required for the procedural review.” The task was a classic fetch mission, a bureaucratic barrier of the most tedious kind. To go from one office to another without the proper forms means to travel in circles, a metaphor for my entire career.

Seeking progress, I visited the Armurerie. The Adjutant there scoffed at my paperwork. “I'd requisition a Durendal! Too bad your forms show none! Return when your armory inventory is properly documented!” His refusal was obvious—easily perceived and intended to block. Needing leverage, I headed to a café near the Préfecture, a place where information was traded more freely than official stamps.

A local bureaucrat, nursing a small cup—an open container for drinking—held court. I leaned in. “Are you acquainted with the Locksmith of the Archives? I hear he's quite skilled with seals.”
The man smirked. “If the Syndicat wants to compete with the Notariat in the Vignes district, they'll need to adopt more aggressive filing procedures.”
His companion snorted. “Aggressive filing? The Syndicat's 'aggression' in Vignes consists of misfiling Form 7-Bis and serving substandard Beaujolais. They lack the *terroir* for proper procedure.”
The first man nodded sagely. “The Notariat has held Vignes since the Third Republic. Our archives contain every vineyard boundary dispute. The Syndicat's 'competition' is like a child scribbling on a master's map.” This rivalry was the class of conflict here—a collection of grievances sharing the common attribute of pettiness.

Suddenly, a predatory calm settled over the table. An Inspector had materialized beside us. “Inspector, please,” he said, his smile thin. “What... no handshake? Come closer.” The arc of the encounter was one of escalating threat, the barrier a direct confrontation. I knew I could—I had the ability to—comply or flee, but both paths were dangerous.

My retreat took me back—toward a former, safer location—through a narrow alley. It was there a Préfecture Agent stepped from the shadows. “Did you not hear my approach?” he sighed, the sound like rustling paper. “Now I must file a report of resistance. How tedious.” Another voice, strained and familiar, echoed from a doorway—the Claimant Brother, trapped in a nightmare of his own making: “What? Who...? Damn, not this dream again. Wake up! Wake up!!”

The Agent ignored him, his focus on me. “Another incident requiring documentation.” The intervention was absolute. As he advanced, his final words were almost gentle: “Please, do not interpret this as a personal failing.” But the meaning was clear. In the end, the only course of action—the expected path—was surrender. The music of
